SgegmaTozoa
UndiluTed Arbacia seminal fluid conTains approx. 2 l0\O spermaTozoa/ml.
One drop oT This "dry sperm" in I0 ml. of sea waTer brings The concenTraTion down
by a TacTor oT 200 To l0?m|. Two drops oi This sTock sperm suspension in l0 ml.
of sea wager conTaining eggs diluTes The sperm concenTraTion by anoTher TacTor of
l00 To I0 sperm/ml. This sperm densiTy is adequaTe Tor TerTilizing small numbers
of eggs. Three Times This much gives abouT The mgximum raTe of TerTilizaTion
wiThouT polyspermy. DensiTies beTween l07 and I0 sperm/ml. resulT in varying
percenTages of polyspermy. UndiluTed sperm will keep in a reTrigeraTor for aT leasT
Two days; diluTion, however, rapidly desTroys Their TerTilizing power. ConsequenTly,
a new sTock sperm suspension should be made up Tor each inseminaTion.
Observe some living spermaTozoa under oil immersion. The acrosome, nucleus
and middle piece are roughly 0.3, l.0 and l.0 microns in lengTh respecTively. The
Tail is abouT 45 microns long and 0.l micron wide; iTs axial TilamenT proTrudes
a shorT disTance beyond The end of The sheaTh. SkeTch a spermaTozoan and describe
iTs movemenT. Place side by side on a slide a drop oT sTock sperm suspension and
a drop of "egg waTer" (supernaTanT from eggs which have sTood Tor an hour or more).
Place a cover-glass over The Two drops so ThaT They mix aT The middle of The cover
glass. NoTe The aggluTinaTion; do The spermaTozoa sTick TogeTher by Their heads or
Tails? Can you deTecT any changes in The sperm acrosome?
Add one ml. of l08/ml sTock sperm suspension To A.9 ml. sea waTer, B. 9 ml.
egg waTer. Observe aT l0 minuTe inTervals. WhaT eTTecT does egg waTer have on The
sperm besides aggluTinaTion? will These sperm acTivaTe eggs?
gva -
Arbacia puncTulaTa eggs compleTe boTh meioTic divisions while in The ovary;
presumably The divisions Themselves musT be rapid, for very seldom are eggs ob-
served wiTh maTuraTion spindles or polar bodies. Unripe gonads oTTen do exhibiT
large numbers of eggs in The germinal vesicle sTage. These will oTTen respond To
inseminaTion by forming hyaline blisTers aT The poinTs of sperm enTrance. AT This
sTage, The mecahnisms for membrane elevaTion and for prevenTing polyspermy have noT
developed. No developmenT resulTs from inseminaTion aT This sTage.
The maTure Arbacia egg has a TransparenT jelly layer ThaT swells To abouT
30 microns in diameTer. MosT of The jelly can be removed if desired by swirling
The eggs for seconds in sea waTer pH 4.5. Longer TreaTmenT removes The jelly
enTirely, buT may injure The eggs. BeneaTh The jelly layer is The viTelline membrane
lT is Too Thin To see on The egg surface, buT is visible as iT e\evaTes from The
surface aT ferTilizaTion. BeneaTh The viTelline membrane is The corTex, conTaining
characTerisTic granules from 0.5 To 0.8 microns in diameTer. The corTex is appar-
enTly an exTra~cellular layer (ParparT and Laris) and in The sea urchins Psammechi-
nus and Arbacia can be removed in sTrips (Allen). The cyToplasm of Arbacia con-
Tains oil spherules, miTochondria, yolk granules and The larger red
echinochrome granules. (As HarTmann (l939) and Taylor (l939) showed, The red
echinochrome is a subsTiTuTed naphThoquinone relaTed To The viTamins.) The
formed cyToplasmic componenTs and The corTical granules are besT seen in cenTriTuged
eggs. The polariTy of The egg can be deTermined only by marking The posiTion of
The micropyle or Tunnel wiTh Janus green or chinese ink. The polar bodies, which
were exTruded aT The animal pole have by This Time been losT in The medium. The
posiTion of The nucleus probably marks The animal Pole only in very unripe eggs
(see Hoadley, l934)
